title: Current in moving loop through magnetic field

content.question: A rectangular conducting loop is moving at constant speed <math alttext="v" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>v</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> into a uniform magnetic field of magnitude <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>B</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that is directed into the page. At the two times <math alttext="t sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="t sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> shown in the figures, the currents in the loop are <math alttext="I sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="I sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, respectively. Which of the following correctly compares currents <math alttext="I sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="I sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> and provides evidence?

choices.label: <math alttext="I sub 2, is less than I sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo><</mo><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because more of the loop is in the field at time <math alttext="t sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="I sub 2, is greater than I sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because it takes more force to move the loop at constant speed at time <math alttext="t sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="I sub 2 equals I sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the current in the loop is zero at both times.

<math alttext="I sub 2 equals I sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the loop experiences the same rate of change in flux at both times.

<math alttext="I sub 2, is greater than I sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>></mo><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because more of the loop is in the field at time <math alttext="t sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: <math alttext="I sub 2 equals I sub 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the loop experiences the same rate of change in flux at both times.
